PSBTGC

Source: vignettes/PSBTGC.Rmd
PSBTGC.Rmd

First, load the package

library(PSBTGC)

PSBTGC comes with the data set Cecchetti (Cecchetti et al., 2011) containing various debt measures; see the reference section for more information.

dat <- Cecchetti %>% 
  select(year, country, gr, gd) %>%
  filter(country %in% c('GB', 'US')) %>%
  group_by(country) %>% 
  mutate(l1gr = lag.series(gr, l = 1),
         l1gd = lag.series(gd, l = 1)) %>%   
  ungroup()
summary(dat[,-c(1,2)])
#>        gr               gd              l1gr             l1gd       
#>  Min.   :-5.787   Min.   :0.4218   Min.   :-2.368   Min.   :0.4218  
#>  1st Qu.: 0.898   1st Qu.:0.5376   1st Qu.: 1.447   1st Qu.:0.5372  
#>  Median : 2.316   Median :0.5989   Median : 2.403   Median :0.5978  
#>  Mean   : 1.732   Mean   :0.6080   Mean   : 1.980   Mean   :0.6001  
#>  3rd Qu.: 3.046   3rd Qu.:0.6714   3rd Qu.: 3.046   3rd Qu.:0.6594  
#>  Max.   : 6.421   Max.   :0.8816   Max.   : 6.421   Max.   :0.7927  
#>                                    NA's   :2        NA's   :2

Simple OLS

In its simplest form, PGranger_SUR with option method = 'OLS' is a simple function that runs OLS equation by equation for all cross-sectional units.

SUR <- PGranger_SUR(dat,
                    dep.var = 'gr', 
                    indep.var = c('l1gr', 'l1gd'), 
                    id.var = 'country', 
                    time.var = 'year', 
                    method ='OLS')
SUR$Coefficient.estimates[,-7]
#>    i Variable Coefficient.Estimates Std..Error  t.statistic      p.value
#> 1 GB       gr            -0.0229971  3.1390480 -0.007326138 0.9942105638
#> 2 GB     l1gr             0.7977132  0.1967992  4.053437697 0.0004066411
#> 3 GB     l1gd             0.5633346  5.8626171  0.096089277 0.9241864902
#> 4 US       gr             2.2628053  2.9425766  0.768987722 0.4488302136
#> 5 US     l1gr             0.4434497  0.2096402  2.115289036 0.0441445752
#> 6 US     l1gd            -2.0555528  4.4827082 -0.458551553 0.6503663213
SUR$Estimation.statistics
#>    i R.squared adj..R.squared     RMSE              AIC              BIC
#> 1 GB 0.4061371     0.36045535 1.709536 444.653646467896 463.337025502555
#> 2 US 0.1483247     0.08281127 2.152368

We can obtain the same results by running R’s standard OLS function lm for each country separately (shown only for the case of Great Britain to save space).

lmGB <- lm(gr ~ l1gr + l1gd, subset(dat, dat$country == 'GB'))
summary(lmGB)
#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = gr ~ l1gr + l1gd, data = subset(dat, dat$country == 
#>     "GB"))
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -5.6343 -0.4879  0.1146  1.0272  2.0801 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  -0.0230     3.1391  -0.007 0.994211    
#> l1gr          0.7977     0.1968   4.053 0.000407 ***
#> l1gd          0.5633     5.8626   0.096 0.924186    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 1.71 on 26 degrees of freedom
#>   (1 observation deleted due to missingness)
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.4061, Adjusted R-squared:  0.3605 
#> F-statistic: 8.891 on 2 and 26 DF,  p-value: 0.001143

PGranger_SUR assumes cross-sectional equation homogeneity. This restriction is relaxed in PGranger2_SUR, which estimates SUR that allows for different estimation equations across countries. We compare the results from PGranger2_SUR with option method = OLS with R’s standard OLS function lm for each country separately. Please note that in this case, PGranger2 requires an object called Equations, which contains the estimation equation for each country and is allowed to vary across countries. It is furthermore necessary to input an intercept term manually.

# Define data set includinc intercept term
dat.PG2 <- dat
dat.PG2$Intercept <- 1
Equations <- list('GB' = as.formula(gr ~ Intercept + l1gr + l1gd),
                  'US' = as.formula(gr ~ Intercept + l1gr))

SUR <- PGranger2_SUR(dat.PG2,
                     Equations = Equations,
                     id.var = 'country', 
                     time.var = 'year', 
                     method ='OLS')
SUR$Coefficient.estimates
#>   id Coefficient  Estimates Std..Error      t.value p.value Sig.
#> 1 GB   Intercept -0.0229971  3.1390480 -0.007326138   0.994     
#> 2 GB        l1gr  0.7977132  0.1967992  4.053437697   0.000  ***
#> 3 GB        l1gd  0.5633346  5.8626171  0.096089277   0.924     
#> 4 US   Intercept  0.9377812  0.5477324  1.712115521   0.098    *
#> 5 US        l1gr  0.4330724  0.2053446  2.109003603   0.044   **

As before, the results are identical to running OLS on a subset of the data using individually specified regression equations.

summary(lm(gr ~ l1gr + l1gd, subset(dat, dat$country == 'GB')))
#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = gr ~ l1gr + l1gd, data = subset(dat, dat$country == 
#>     "GB"))
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -5.6343 -0.4879  0.1146  1.0272  2.0801 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  -0.0230     3.1391  -0.007 0.994211    
#> l1gr          0.7977     0.1968   4.053 0.000407 ***
#> l1gd          0.5633     5.8626   0.096 0.924186    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 1.71 on 26 degrees of freedom
#>   (1 observation deleted due to missingness)
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.4061, Adjusted R-squared:  0.3605 
#> F-statistic: 8.891 on 2 and 26 DF,  p-value: 0.001143
summary(lm(gr ~ l1gr , subset(dat, dat$country == 'US')))
#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = gr ~ l1gr, data = subset(dat, dat$country == "US"))
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -5.7126 -0.7860  0.2143  1.1686  4.0609 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)  
#> (Intercept)   0.9378     0.5477   1.712   0.0983 .
#> l1gr          0.4331     0.2053   2.109   0.0444 *
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.121 on 27 degrees of freedom
#>   (1 observation deleted due to missingness)
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.1414, Adjusted R-squared:  0.1096 
#> F-statistic: 4.448 on 1 and 27 DF,  p-value: 0.04436

Two-step FGLS

One can obtain results of the SUR procedure in different ways. For one, PGranger_SUR with option method = 'SUR' corresponds to the procedure in @Konya2006 and @Puente2015, which assumes identical lag lengths for all countries. This is demonstrated below for the sample data set and a simple VAR(1).

SUR1 <- PGranger_SUR(dat, 
                     dep.var = 'gr', 
                     indep.var = c('l1gr', 'l1gd'), 
                     id.var = 'country', 
                     time.var = 'year', 
                     method ='SUR')
SUR1$Coefficient.estimates[,-7]
#>    i Variable Coefficient  Estimates Std.Error      t.stat Sig.
#> 1 GB       gr   Intercept  0.8604758 2.6580823  0.32372051     
#> 2 GB     l1gr        l1gr  0.6181728 0.1748799  3.53484263   **
#> 3 GB     l1gd        l1gd -0.3619740 4.9422204 -0.07324117     
#> 4 US       gr   Intercept  0.7758007 2.4976138  0.31061675     
#> 5 US     l1gr        l1gr  0.3062617 0.1869983  1.63777854     
#> 6 US     l1gd        l1gd  0.6071935 3.7800097  0.16063280

We can verify these results by comparing them with the output obtained by the R packages systemfit, as shown below.

# Using systemfit
library(systemfit)
library(plm)
X <- dat[, c('year', 'country', 'gr', 'l1gr', 'l1gd')]
# systemfit is a bit picky with id names
X$country <- ifelse(X$country == 'GB', 'G',
                    ifelse(X$country == 'Canada', 'C',
                           ifelse(X$country == 'US', 'U',NA))) 
colnames(X) <- c('year','country','y','a','b')
sf <- systemfit(y ~ a +b, method = 'SUR', data= plm.data(X, c("country","year")))
summary(sf)
#> 
#> systemfit results 
#> method: SUR 
#> 
#>         N DF     SSR detRCov   OLS-R2 McElroy-R2
#> system 58 52 202.609  8.5715 0.247865   0.187912
#> 
#>    N DF     SSR     MSE    RMSE       R2   Adj R2
#> G 29 26  78.891 3.03427 1.74192 0.383428 0.336000
#> U 29 26 123.718 4.75837 2.18137 0.125219 0.057928

#>         G       U

#> U 2.42212 4.75837

#> Multiple R-Squared: 0.125219 Adjusted R-Squared: 0.057928

The same results can be obtained using PGranger2_SUR with option method = 'SUR'. If the list of equations is identical for all countries, it generates the identical results as when using PGranger_SUR or systemfit.

# Setting up equations for SUR
Equations <- list('GB' = as.formula(gr ~ Intercept + l1gr + l1gd), 
                  'US' = as.formula(gr ~ Intercept + l1gr + l1gd))

SUR2 <- PGranger2_SUR(dat.PG2,
                      Equations = Equations,
                      id.var = 'country', 
                      time.var = 'year', 
                      method ='SUR', 
                      for.BS = FALSE)
SUR2$Coefficient.estimates
#>   id Coefficient  Estimates Std..Error     t.value p.value Sig.
#> 1 GB   Intercept  0.8604758  2.6580823  0.32372051   0.751     
#> 2 GB        l1gr  0.6181728  0.1748799  3.53484263   0.004   **
#> 3 GB        l1gd -0.3619740  4.9422204 -0.07324117   0.943     
#> 4 US   Intercept  0.7758007  2.4976138  0.31061675   0.761     
#> 5 US        l1gr  0.3062617  0.1869983  1.63777854   0.125     
#> 6 US        l1gd  0.6071935  3.7800097  0.16063280   0.875

Lastly, we PGranger2_SUR allows for varying estimation equations which can easily be specified in the Equations input argument.

# Setting up equations for SUR
Equations <- list('GB' = as.formula(gr ~ Intercept + l1gr + l1gd), 
                  'US' = as.formula(gr ~ Intercept + l1gr ))

SUR2 <- PGranger2_SUR(dat.PG2,
                      Equations = Equations,
                      id.var = 'country', 
                      time.var = 'year', 
                      method ='SUR', for.BS = FALSE)
SUR2$Coefficient.estimates
#>   id Coefficient  Estimates Std..Error     t.value p.value Sig.
#> 1 GB   Intercept  0.8351611  2.5716186  0.32476085   0.751     
#> 2 GB        l1gr  0.6081488  0.1707867  3.56086783   0.003   **
#> 3 GB        l1gd -0.2769850  4.7720810 -0.05804281   0.955     
#> 4 US   Intercept  1.1821788  0.5231771  2.25961500   0.041   **
#> 5 US        l1gr  0.3012489  0.1834792  1.64186903   0.125
